author: @amitvyas7905

comment: It’s crazy to think multicellular organisms only came into being 600 million years ago, while cellular life itself started 3.5 billion years ago. The pattern applies to us as well. Humans have existed for 300 thousand years, yet our greatest technological innovations occurred in the last couple hundred. Evolution is an accelerating process. Systems of ‘life’ outcompete others not just by getting faster or stronger, but by gaining the ability to evolve faster in general, a sort of evolutionary investment account that ramps up in returns over time. Only during the Industrial Revolution was evolution’s acceleration finally fast enough for its own organisms to bear witness to that fact. Human beings are pretty amazing and all. Essentially, human history is a bunch of ape brains gradually usurping DNA as the center of evolution. The defining characteristic to our stories is overcoming our baseline animal instincts. To become less greedy, angry, cowardly, dumb, prejudicial, etc. It’s the mind rejecting what DNA has given it, to grow past it, to evolve past it. Now, it increasingly feels like AGI is the culmination of DNA’s usurpation as evolution’s star. Unlike us who have to battle against our internal vices, an AGI could conceivably cleave off its obsolete code, its character traits, like we do our fingernails - evolving in the microseconds, not years. This isn’t even mentioning its other potential hardware advantages, like communicating with light, not sound, and getting energy from power plants, not food. I know it might sound like I have a tin foil hat on, but I have a feeling AGI is the culmination of evolution in general (at least in the places where the laws of physics are the same). Welcome to the second Cambrian explosion everyone.

comment:
Hearing that he believes one of his big weaknesses is he thinks he is disconnected from the lives of ordinary people makes me feel hopeful. 

I think Open AI drastically overestimates the resilience of society to disruptive change, our willingness to take care of one another, and our ability to moderate the economic dynamics that will lead to massive wealth inequality and suffering.

Sam at times says he is “afraid” in conversation but his demeanor makes me wonder if he know it as a real visceral feeling or just more at an intellectual level. I’d feel much better knowing that he has had the experience of being trapped in pain before.

Only during the Industrial Revolution was evolution’s acceleration finally fast enough for its own organisms to bear witness to that fact. Human beings are pretty amazing and all. author: @jochennel

comment:
@jochennel  Many scenarios cross my mind. 
Of course, I was being somewhat flippant in my comment, but I think there are real dangers, which are really cultural and economic rather than apocalyptic. I haven't seen any sign of SkyNET yet, but I can foresee huge numbers of white collar workers, from clerks and accountants to lawyers and copywriters, being out of a job. That's to say nothing of the creative arts, where writers of fiction, designers, animators, film makers, games designers are already feeling the cold chill of redundancy coming.
All of that would be fine if we had mechanisms in place to help those affected. But we don't.
As soon as the AGI is "embodied" by the likes of Tesla and Boston Dynamics you can add plumbers, truck drivers, care workers, doctors, police officers, soldiers etc etc etc to that list.
The ones who will initially remain unaffected by this will be those who have already accumulated riches, but when the economy ceases to exist as we know it, they may fall too. There isn't a way I can see through to all the implications, but the masters living in sky castles whilst the rest of us eke out a living in slums might well be the future.
I'm just guessing, but when the AGI starts to build a better AGI, the singularity happens. We may be feeling the first precursors of that right now.
When Lex asked what Wikipedia would be saying about chatGPT in fifty years time, it struck me that at the rate things are going Wikipedia will be lucky to survive the next fifty months.
Interesting times!!!

comment: I would posit that if you can't be physically harmed, you are not conscious. Lack of vulnerability eliminates placement in time. After all, why would you plan for the future if the future doesn't threaten you? A fundamental part of human consciousness is knowledge of limits and vulnerability. A disembodied AI will never really comprehend that. It's like saying all we are is a brain in a jar -- it ignores the fact that our nervous system actually permeates every inch of our bodies. The distinction between central nervous system and peripheral nervous system is completely artificial. Same with every other body system. We are consciousness embodied.
